title: Infamous 4: Where could it go next? | Trusted Reviews
description:
![Infamous: Second
Son](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-

It’s hard to believe that Sucker Punch’s [Infamous: Second
Son](https://www.trustedreviews.com/infamous-second-son-review) launched on
[PS4](https://www.trustedreviews.com/ps4-pro-review) more than three years
ago. One of the first big exclusives for Sony’s console, it gave players the
opportunity to explore a stylish open world with awesome superpowers. All
things considered, it was a great adventure with some truly gorgeous visuals.
Although, it didn’t quite reach the heights of its predecessors.

If Sucker Punch is working on another entry in its superhero series, we know
exactly what we’d love to see. _TrustedReviews_ has compiled all the latest
news, rumours, trailers, gameplay and more for Infamous 4.

**Related:[Call of Duty: WWII](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/call-of-
duty-ww2-release-date-trailers-multiplayer-gameplay-pre-order-screenshots-
system-requirements)**  
![Infamous: Second
Son](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

## What is Infamous 4?

We know very little about Infamous 4 so far. Will it continue the story of
lovable rogue Delsin Rowe, following the ***spoilers*** tragic passing of his
brother towards the end of Second Son? His character had a ton of potential,
and we’d love to see it expanded upon in a sequel.

## Infamous 4 release date – When is it coming out?

It’s unlikely to be coming our way anytime soon, with rumours suggesting that
Sucker Punch’s next game will be a brand-new IP. But that’s not to say that a
sequel is off the table altogether.

**Related:[Best PS4 Games](https://www.trustedreviews.com/best-
ps4-games_round-up)**  
  
[E3 2017](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/e3-2017-games-news-trailers)
would be the perfect time to spill the beans if Infamous 4 is in the works.

**Take advantage of PS4 Pro**

Despite launching over three years ago, Infamous: Second Son is still a
beautiful game to look at. A dynamic open world filled with unique NPCs and
fluorescent particle effects, Delsin’s powers took great advantage of Sony’s
burgeoning hardware. Now that [PS4
Pro](https://www.trustedreviews.com/ps4-pro-review) is out in the wild, we
seriously want to see the Infamous series on a more powerful console.

We’ve already seen the likes of [Horizon: Zero
Dawn](https://www.trustedreviews.com/horizon-zero-dawn-review) and [The Last
of Us: Remastered](https://www.trustedreviews.com/the-last-of-us-remastered-
review) putting the newly released system to brilliant use.
[HDR](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/hdr-tv-high-dynamic-television-
explained) and [4K](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/4k-tv-10-reasons-
why-you-should-care) checkerboarding should make for a visually spectacular
package once Infamous 4 rolls around.  
**  
An improved setting**

Be honest, Infamous: Second Son’s adaptation of Seattle was a little
miserable. The dingy backstreets and rain-drenched cityscape was a joy to
climb upon and looked lovely, but it simply wasn’t very fun to explore outside
of the story missions. Side activities were little more than repetitive combat
trials and gimmicky mini-games with little to no substance.

**Related:[Uncharted 5
wishlist](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/uncharted-5-release-date-
gameplay-rumours-wishlist-traiiler-news)**

We want Infamous 4 to break new ground with a setting that strikes a new
standard in terms of size and scope. When compared to the likes of other PS4
exclusives such as [Uncharted
4](https://www.trustedreviews.com/uncharted-4-review) and
[Bloodborne](https://www.trustedreviews.com/bloodborne-review), the world of
previous Infamous games feel miniscule. They’re still great fun, but simply
don’t match up to their contemporaries.

**A better morality system**

Infamous: Second Son has an entertaining morality system, although it was
limited to being incredibly good or downright evil. Settling for a neutral
middle-ground felt pointless, as you were stuck with hardly any worthwhile
powers to upgrade. Cut-scenes also saw Delsin acting like a goody-two-shoes or
an obnoxious asshat. At times, it felt jarring and unconvincing, lessening the
impact of a generic yet entertaining narrative.

**Related:[Star Wars Battlefront 2 latest
news](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/star-wars-battlefront-2-release-
date-gameplay-trailer-preorder)**  
![infamous](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

One way to remedy such a transparent system could be through the addition of
dialogue choices for the player. [The Witcher
3](https://www.trustedreviews.com/the-witcher-3-wild-hunt-review) had you
forming Geralt’s moral compass as you progressed. Even [Mass Effect:
Andromeda](https://www.trustedreviews.com/mass-effect-andromeda-review)
evolved that series’ morality system to include a healthy shade of grey to the
mix, so that the choices you made in the opening moments didn’t dictate every
move until the credits rolled. None of your words were guided by red/blue
options indicating the consequence of each word. Sucker Punch needn’t hold our
hand, and may improve its narrative as a result.

**Two playable characters**

Infamous: Second Son had a fantastic expansion in the form of Infamous: First
Light. You played as Fetch, a rebellious young woman with superpowers of her
own. Despite its brevity, First Light was an excellent glimpse of Sucker
Punch’s capabilities outside of its usual framework. It told a tragic story of
death, betrayal and eventual triumph for Fetch. She’s a great character, and
would work well alongside Delsin Rowe if Infamous 4 becomes a reality.

Two playable protagonists could also lend the moment-to-moment gameplay an
essential dose of variety. Having two suites of unique superpowers to
experiment with and upgrade would make switching between the two an event to
look forward to. That is, so long as they’re both perfectly capable of dishing
out some damage and navigating the open world.
